required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Time to Conceive: A Study of Fertility
clinical_study.official_title: Time to Conceive: A Study of Fertility: Biomarkers of Fertility

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to learn a way to measure a person's fertility. After 1 year of trying, 1 out of every 7 women will not be pregnant. This is called infertility. This results in significant distress and anxiety. Infertility is common; however, the investigators have no markers to predict who will be infertile. For couples diagnosed with infertility, the investigators have used blood and urine hormone levels (follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), inhibin B, and antimullerian hormone (AMH)) to tell us who will get pregnant with fertility treatment. The investigators don't know if these hormone levels can predict if regular people trying to get pregnant will be able to get pregnant. This study will try to determine if these hormone levels can predict fertility and infertility.

arm_group.description: Study participants will not be asked to make any changes to their daily lifestyle or existing health care routine. Participants also will not be asked to take any medications or change their diet.

intervention.description: Study participants will not be asked to make any changes to their daily lifestyle or existing health care routine. Participants also will not be asked to take any medications or change their diet.

study_pop.textblock: Healthy women living in Chapel Hill, Raleigh, Durham, and the surrounding communities of the Triangle Area in North Carolina.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- women between the ages of 30 and 44
- hoping to get pregnant and about to start trying or have been trying for less than 3 months
- living with male partner
Exclusion Criteria:
- currently using birth control with no intention of stopping
- have been trying to get pregnant for more than 3 months
- have used hormone shots for birth control in the past year
- have renal failure
- have known fertility problems, such as polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
- plan on moving outside of the Triangle Area in the next 6 months

overall_official.affiliation: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

facility.name: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
